rows.title: Praise yourself

transcript.eng:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: “This week, I am proud of myself for …” It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

rows.transcript:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: “This week, I am proud of myself for …” It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

text_1.eng: Being a great parent also means taking time to care for yourself every day. It starts with recognising how you feel.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: So good to hear you are feeling well today. You are incredible!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: We all have days where we just don’t know. That is okay! You are here and that is what matters.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Being a parent can be hard. But you are here and that shows you want to keep improving things. That is a big accomplishment already!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Being a parent can be hard. But you are here and that shows you want to keep improving things. That is a big accomplishment already!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Our topic today is staying safe.

To keep our teens safe, we need to understand their reality and the potential risky situations they can find themselves in.

We can help our teens know how to use their thoughts, voice, AND body in dangerous situations. It makes a big difference!

media_title.eng: How will it help me and my family?

media_transcript.eng:
Our topic is staying safe.

As parents it is important to ensure that our teens are safe at all times. Our safety and our children’s safety is important. We may need to have discussions with our children about their safety, and how they can keep themselves safe always.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Our topic today is staying safe.

To keep our teens safe, we need to understand their reality and the potential risky situations they can find themselves in.

We can help our teens know how to use their thoughts, voice, AND body in dangerous situations. It makes a big difference!
rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Our topic is staying safe.

As parents it is important to ensure that our teens are safe at all times. Our safety and our children’s safety is important. We may need to have discussions with our children about their safety, and how they can keep themselves safe always.

media_title.eng:
Hear a caregiver's testimonial

Placeholder text - Anna - we need a title similar to the above

media_transcript.eng:
Learning how to stay safe really helped us. The other day, my daughter got invited to a party by an older boy, and he said he would pay for her transport. Before, she would just go secretly, but now she came to me to talk about it.

We reminded each other that it is important to see the warning signs and stay safe, and she decided to say ‘no’. I am so proud of her. Even me, I now know that others should not pressure or convince me to do something. I can give the right example to my children.

rows.media_title:
Hear a caregiver's testimonial

Placeholder text - Anna - we need a title similar to the above
rows.media_transcript:
Learning how to stay safe really helped us. The other day, my daughter got invited to a party by an older boy, and he said he would pay for her transport. Before, she would just go secretly, but now she came to me to talk about it.

We reminded each other that it is important to see the warning signs and stay safe, and she decided to say ‘no’. I am so proud of her. Even me, I now know that others should not pressure or convince me to do something. I can give the right example to my children.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
People around us can make us feel respected, happy and safe. But sometimes, people can pressure us and make us feel uncomfortable. This can happen to teenagers and adults.

When we know the warning signs, we can try and stop the situation to stay safe.

Let’s look at some scenarios.

text_2.eng: Boyfriend pressures @data.characters.female_child_1.name to go beyond kissing

character_1_text.eng: I don't think I am ready..

character_2_text.eng: Oh come on... We are ready for the next step. We see each other all the time and we never do anything more… You know I love you, right!

quiz_1_question.eng:
What warning signs do you see here?

The boyfriend:

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Does not listen to @data.characters.female_child_1.name or ask what she wants

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, these are clear warning signs! Your partner (or anyone else) should never try to push or convince you to do something you do not want to do or feel unsure about. Even if you do something once, this does not mean you have to do it again – you are allowed to change your mind at any time, even during an intimate moment.

A partner who really loves and respects you will ask if you are okay, listen to you, and stop if you want to. They would never push you into something you do not want to do.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
Yes, these are clear warning signs! Your partner (or anyone else) should never try to push or convince you to do something you do not want to do or feel unsure about. Even if you do something once, this does not mean you have to do it again – you are allowed to change your mind at any time, even during an intimate moment.

A partner who really loves and respects you will ask if you are okay, listen to you, and stop if you want to. They would never push you into something you do not want to do.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Makes @data.characters.female_child_1.name feel bad about how she acts

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
Yes, these are clear warning signs! Your partner (or anyone else) should never try to push or convince you to do something you do not want to do or feel unsure about. People around us can make us feel respected, happy and safe. But sometimes, people can pressure us and make us feel uncomfortable. This can happen to teenagers and adults.

rows.character_1_text: I don't think I am ready..

character_2_text.eng: No, you are staying here. You always leave me alone to go see your friends. Don’t you love me? Or are you meeting your other boyfriend?!

quiz_1_question.eng:
What warning signs do you see here?

The boyfriend:

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs! When we are in love, it can be hard to recognise something is wrong in our relationship.

If you have a friend in @data.characters.female_child_1.name’s situation, try to help them see that jealous, possessive or controlling behaviour is not healthy or loving.

text_2.eng: @data.characters.male_child_2.name’s friend shouts sexual comment at girl

character_1_text.eng: Hey pretty, why are you walking so fast! Don’t you want to come show us what is under that skirt?

quiz_1_question.eng:
What warning signs do you see here?

The friend:

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs! Shouting sexual comments, whistling or making kissing sounds at someone is sexual harassment and a type of sexual abuse.

If @data.characters.male_child_2.name stays silent, his friend will likely keep doing this. @data.characters.male_child_2.name can help his friend see that his behaviour makes girls feel scared, angry, or sad, and is not okay.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Makes the girl feel uncomfortable about how she looks and acts

quiz_1_question.eng: What warning signs do you see here?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs! It is common for young women to be pressured into sex when men offer food, gifts, or money.

Whenever you do not get the space to make your own decisions, that can be dangerous. Your friends, and others, should respect your choices.

text_2.eng: Teacher asks @data.characters.female_child_1.name to stay after scool

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.female_child_1.name, if you want to get good grades this year you need to stay after school when everyone is gone so I can tutor you.

character_2_text.eng: My friend also needs support. Can I invite her too?

character_3_text.eng: No, this will be our secret. You don't want people to think you are stupid, right?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, all of these are warning signs! Schools have strict rules to keep students safe. The teacher is abusing his power and knows that what he is doing is wrong.

Probably, he has tried this before and will do it again, so @data.characters.female_child_1.name could try to find others with the same experience to make it easier to report the teacher to an adult who she trusts.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
When we do not feel safe, we are allowed to do, say, and believe anything that helps keep us safe. The goal is to get away!

Let’s think about the scenario when @data.characters.female_child_4.name  was forced into a car by a man.

How could @data.characters.female_child_4.name  use her voice to get away?

rows.text_1_facilitator:
When we do not feel safe, we are allowed to do, say, and believe anything that helps keep us safe. The goal is to get away!

Let’s think about the scenario when @data.characters.female_child_4.name  was forced into a car by a man.

How could @data.characters.female_child_4.name  use her voice to get away?

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s think back of @data.characters.female_child_4.name ’s dangerous situation.

quiz_1_question.eng: Could this situation happen to a boy?

quiz_2_question.eng: Could a boy use his voice to get away?

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Boys and girls can both find themselves in dangerous situations. Both boys and girls are allowed to do, say, and believe anything that will help them stay safe.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Boys and girls can both find themselves in dangerous situations. Both boys and girls are allowed to do, say, and believe anything that will help them stay safe.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
When our voice does not stop the situation, we can use our bodies to defend ourselves.

@data.characters.female_child_4.name ’s attacker has some weak spots she can target in order to get away. The same can work for you:

text_2.eng:
Eyes:
- Use your fingers as claws and scratch the attacker’s face as hard as possible.
- Push your thumbs into the eye sockets of your attacker and then outward towards the sides of their head.
Throat:
- Push your finger into the hole at the bottom of the attacker’s throat.
- Punch the throat with your fist or back of your elbow.
Groin:
- Kick the attacker’s groin with your knee, or punch it with your fist or elbow.
- Grab, squeeze, twist and pull the attacker’s testicles with your hand.
Knees:
- Kick against your attacker’s knee with your foot.

section_1_text.eng:
Use your fingers as claws and scratch the attacker’s face as hard as possible.

Push your thumbs into the eye sockets of your attacker and then outward towards the sides of their head.

section_2_text.eng:
Push your finger into the hole at the bottom of the attacker’s throat.

Punch the throat with your fist or back of your elbow.

section_3_text.eng:
Kick the attacker’s groin with your knee, or punch it with your fist or elbow.

Grab, squeeze, twist and pull the attacker’s testicles with your hand.

section_4_text.eng: Kick against your attacker's knee with your foot.

rows.section_1_text:
Use your fingers as claws and scratch the attacker’s face as hard as possible.

Push your thumbs into the eye sockets of your attacker and then outward towards the sides of their head.
rows.section_2_text:
Push your finger into the hole at the bottom of the attacker’s throat.

Punch the throat with your fist or back of your elbow.
rows.section_3_text:
Kick the attacker’s groin with your knee, or punch it with your fist or elbow.

Grab, squeeze, twist and pull the attacker’s testicles with your hand.
rows.section_4_text: Kick against your attacker's knee with your foot.

text_2.eng:
Temples:
- Punch the attacker’s temples with your fist or the back of your elbow.
Nose:
- Punch the attacker’s nose with your fist or the back of your elbow.
Ears:
- With flat hands, smack the attacker’s ears from both sides as hard as possible. You can also pull or twist them.
Ribs:
- Punch the attacker in the ribs with your fist or the back of your elbow.
Fingers:
- Pull the attackers pinky or little finger away from the other fingers hard and fast (it breaks easily).
Shins:
- Kick against the attacker’s shins as hard as you can.
Top of feet:
- Lift your foot and stomp your heel on the top of your attacker’s foot.

- Punch the attacker’s temples with your fist or the back of your elbow.

Ribs:

Fingers:
- Pull the attackers pinky or little finger away from the other fingers hard and fast (it breaks easily).
Shins:
- Kick against the attacker’s shins as hard as you can.
Top of feet:
- Lift your foot and stomp your heel on the top of your attacker’s foot.

text_2.eng: Here are some examples of how you can use the weak spots or targets on your attacker’s body.

rows.text_2: Here are some examples of how you can use the weak spots or targets on your attacker’s body.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are this week’s takeaway skills!

section_1_text.eng:
Know the difference between healthy and unhealthy relationships. If you are attacked, know that it is never your fault. You are allowed to say and do what is needed to stay safe and get away – do not worry about what others may think.

You are worth defending. You are strong and powerful.

section_2_text.eng:
When someone makes you (or someone else) feel uncomfortable with what they say or do, that is never okay! We all have the right to feel safe, especially at home.

See the warning signs and follow your feeling. When you feel attacked with words or actions, your goal is to get away.

section_3_text.eng:
Your voice can stop many attacks. Yell ‘No!’, call for help, warn of consequences, name the behaviour, act crazy, pretend to go along to buy time, use humour, calm them down, or negotiate.

Be clear, confident and direct. Speak using your voice, body language and eye contact.

section_4_text.eng:
When our voice is not changing the situation, we can use our bodies.

Know the ‘weapons’ on your body and know the ‘targets’ on your attacker’s body. Use what is free on your body that you can fight with and what is open on the attacker’s body to hit.

section_4_extra_text.eng:
In a dangerous situation, we may not know what to do and freeze – this is normal. These tools can help you and your teen stay safe.

If you as a teen or parent do get hurt by someone, remember it is never your fault. Ask someone you trust for help.

As a parent, make sure your teen knows they can tell you anything, so you can find a solution together.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are this week’s takeaway skills!
rows.section_1_text:
Know the difference between healthy and unhealthy relationships. If you are attacked, know that it is never your fault. You are allowed to say and do what is needed to stay safe and get away – do not worry about what others may think.

You are worth defending. You are strong and powerful.
rows.section_2_text:
When someone makes you (or someone else) feel uncomfortable with what they say or do, that is never okay! We all have the right to feel safe, especially at home.

See the warning signs and follow your feeling. When you feel attacked with words or actions, your goal is to get away.
rows.section_3_text:
Your voice can stop many attacks. Yell ‘No!’, call for help, warn of consequences, name the behaviour, act crazy, pretend to go along to buy time, use humour, calm them down, or negotiate.

Be clear, confident and direct. Speak using your voice, body language and eye contact.
rows.section_4_text:
When our voice is not changing the situation, we can use our bodies.

Know the ‘weapons’ on your body and know the ‘targets’ on your attacker’s body. Use what is free on your body that you can fight with and what is open on the attacker’s body to hit.
rows.section_4_extra_text:
In a dangerous situation, we may not know what to do and freeze – this is normal. These tools can help you and your teen stay safe.

If you as a teen or parent do get hurt by someone, remember it is never your fault. Ask someone you trust for help.

As a parent, make sure your teen knows they can tell you anything, so you can find a solution together.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Small actions, big results! Parents who practice their module skills at home get better results.

This week's homa activity is to discuss the Staying Safe module with your teens.

You can even do the activities on warning signs and how to use our voice and body together.

It can be hard to talk about these topics together, but it will give your teen skills for situations when they need it most. You can do it!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Small actions, big results! Parents who practice their module skills at home get better results.

This week's homa activity is to discuss the Staying Safe module with your teens.

You can even do the activities on warning signs and how to use our voice and body together.

It can be hard to talk about these topics together, but it will give your teen skills for situations when they need it most. You can do it!

media_title.eng:
Hear a teen's testimonial

Placeholder - Anna, context needed here

media_transcript.eng: It helped me a lot that I learnt I can use my voice to stay safe. A while ago, I was walking home alone and some man began to follow me and I felt scared. My father taught me that the most important thing is to be safe, so I turned around and said loud and clear ‘Why are you following me, I don’t want that’. It really surprised the man and even some other people looked at us, so the man walked away. I felt so relieved and even told my father. He said I did well and I felt really good. Before, I would have been too scared, also what other people think, but now I feel confident.

My father taught me that the most important thing is to be safe, so I turned around and said loud and clear ‘Why are you following me, I don’t want that’. It really surprised the man and even some other people looked at us, so the man walked away. I felt so relieved and even told my father. He said I did well and I felt really good.
